HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 5, 1961

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Dr. Dintzis To Head Medical Grad Students To Visit
And Hygiene Biophysics Dept. Williamsburg Meeting
The appointment of Dr. Howard M. Dintzis as professor of
biophysics and chairman of the
joint department of biophysics
of the Johns Hopkins University
School of Medicine and the
School of Hygiene and Public
Health was announced today by
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, President of the University.
Dr. Dintzis, who received his
bachelor's degree from the University of California and his
doctorate in biophysical chemistry from the Harvard Medical
School, is now a senior research
associate in the department of
biology of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Eisenhower's Statement
In announcing the appointment, Dr. Eisenhower declared:
"The Johns Hopkins University has been fortunate to obtain, in Dr. Dintzis, a brilliant
investigator and teacher in the
field of biophysics, one of the
newest and most significant of
the life sciences.
"Because of the important deexperimental
velopments in
biology ... the faculty has felt
that the training of medical
students in this modern age
would be incomplete without
some appreciation and knowledge of the field of biophysics.
Need Academic Department
"For this reason, the Johns
Hopkins University has decided
to develop a large and significant academic department in
biophysics at its School of Medi-

cine and School of Hygiene and
Public Health and to provide
instruction in biophysics to students at both the elementary and
advanced levels.
"Only a very few medical
schools in the country have such
programs and we hope that this
development, planned on a large
scale, will provide the spearhead
for the foundation of medical
theory and practice on the
fundamental biological, chemical and physical principles that
govern the behavior of molecules
within cells"
To Occupy New Building
Dr. Dintzis, whose appointment becomes effective July 1,
and his department, will occupy
the $1,000,000, four-story Biophysics Building, just completed
at the School of Medicine.

Dr. Dintzis received his bachelor's degree in 1948 and his
Ph.D. in 1953. He then spent two
years as a research fellow in
the molecular biology unit of
the Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, England.
From Cal. Tech.
In 1956, he became assistant
professor of chemistry in the
California Institute of Technology. He was appointed to his
present position at M.I.T. in
1953.
Dr. Dintzis is regarded as an
authority in the structure and
biosynthesis of large molecules
and has made important scientific contributions to the x-ray
analysis of protein structure.

Student Council Plans
Next Year's Activities
The details of getting off the
ground and the sketching in of
tentative plans for some of next
year's activities occupied the
second meeting of the newly
elected Student Council last
Wednesday.
Council President Bob Abernethy announced that- a new
S.C. constitution is in the works
and will probably be presented

to the student body for approval
some time early next year.
It was also announced that
President Milton Eisenhower will
establish a series of informal gettogethers with the Council at his
home next year. These are to be
strictly social events which; it is
hoped, will bring about a greater
mutual understanding between
faculty and students.

Two Johns Hokins University
graduate students have been selected to attend the fifth annual
Williamsburg International Assembly to be held at Williamsburg, Virginia June 11-14.
Guillermo Alarcon of the Department of Sanitary_ Engineering and Luther A. Bourne, a student at the School of Advanced
International Studies, are among
the fifty-two delegates who will
attend.
To be eligible for attendance
a student must be a citizen of a
country other than the United
States who plans to return home
before the start of the next
academic year. He must also
have completed at least one year
of graduate-level study by the
end of the present academic
year.
A native of Bolivia, Mr. Alarcon is being sponsored in the
Department of Engineering by
the Organization of American
States.
Mr. Bourne, whose home is in
the West Indies, is an officer in
the Federal Public Service of the
Federation of the West Indies.
He was sent to SIAS for specialized training by the Prime Minister's Department of the West
Indies.
The topic of the conference will
be "The American Cultural
Scene: Roots and Realities." Informal presentations, question
and answer sessions and general

Hopkins Apathy: What Me Worr And Folk Concert
By MIKE MAKOyER
One of the average Hopkins
student's most serious deficiencies is a lack of any detailed
knowledge about what goes on
in the world. In a recent NewsLetter current events poll the
average score was only 40%.
Twenty questions on current
events were asked of dormitory
students of all classes and
majors. The questions were designed to test a fairly detailed
knowledge of world affairs and
to eliminate blind guessing.
Social science majors made top
scores, followed by students in
the humanities, biological sciences, sciences, and engineering—in descending order. By
class, seniors led, trailed by

juniors, sophomores, and freshmen.
Results on individual questions raised some interesting
points. For example, though
peace organizations and UnAmerican Activities Committee
groups are active at Hopkins,
only 30% of the students knew
that the House had overwhelmingly approved and voted funds
for the Committee.
Again, only 30% could answer
questions on Lao-s, the Congo,
and the U.N., all of which have
been very much in the news. A
surprising 70% did not know that
Lord Home is Foreign Minister
of Great Britain. Less surprising
was the fact that 70% did not
know that Conakry is the capi-

tal of Guinea, or that John Connally is Secretary of the Navy.
The only excuse offered for
low scores was lack of time to
read newspapers. A few students
thought that the questions were
ambiguous, but even if the average score is pro-rated for ambiguity and testing error, its
highest level is 50%, which is not
significantly better.
A minor question asked for
the name of the President of
Russia. The 70% who did not
know the answer (Brezhnev)
guessed Vorlinskya completely
fictitious name.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter this week passes
into the hands of a new editorship. As the newly selected
continuous
staff prepares itself to enter our 65th year of
publication, a restatement of policy and aims is in order.
First, the News-Letter fully recognizes\ its responsibility to provide full carerage for the manifold functions
Howof the various campus organizations and activities.

support to worthwhile events and functions, the NewsLetter shall not degenerate into a campus publicity organ.

should be recognized as such, and not as deliberate or
malicious slanting of news.
The News-Letter shall maintain tradition by taking
firm stands on campus issues when the situations warrant
such editorial action. We shall break with tradition by
supporting one candidate or the other in major campus
elections should a case arise in which the issues or personalities involved are clear cut enough.
In a concerted attempt to improve the journalistic
quality of the paper, we shall expand our campus coverage
to encompass hitherto neglected areas such as cultural
affairs, meetings and lectures. In addition our news and
feature columns will include items concerning off-campus
activities of interest to Hopkins men, both in the City of
Baltimore and on other neighboring campuses.
The manifold issues of civil liberties and racial
equality have attracted much interest on the Hopkins
campus this year as in past years. The News-Letter shall
try to elucidate and comment on these issues and the
actions taken thereupon in order to help bring about a
greater degree of equality, both on and off the campus.
This is in accordance with long' established News-Letter
policy.
As a final break with tradition, the News-Letter will
no longer refrain from commenting upon and taking firm
stands on major national and international issues. While
our principal function is as a campus organ, there are
,often timely issues in the daily newspapers which warrant
student opinion and reaction in the nature of editorials
and news analyses. This shall be a fairly regular feature
of a News-Letter truly representative of student activities,
opinion and attitudes.

Wickwire Presents

By MATT iCRENSON

Dr. Albert Hammond, after half a century
spent with the queen of Arts and the sport of
kings, has announced that he will retire from
daytime teaching at Hopkins this June.
Dr. Hammond, Associate Professor of Philosophy, began his association with the University
in 1910 when he arrived at the old Howard
Street campus as a freshman. Today he recalls
that the location at Howard and Ross Streets
was somewhat superior to the present Homewood site in that the width of Ross Street was
ideal for pitching nickels.
As an undergraduate, Dr. Hamomnd was a
member of the "historical-political group"
(there were no department majors), and he
took the required courses—English composition,
literature, physics and philosophy, which in
those days covered ethics, psychology, and logic
in one year.
In 1914, he turned to teaching—at first in
public speaking and later, in philosophy.
DR. ALBERT L. HAMMOND
It was during these early days on the faculty that Dr. Hammond struck
up a friendship with Arthur 0.
Lovejoy, said by many scholars
to be among America's few outstanding philosophers. One of
Dr. Hammond's associateS has
noted that Dr. Hammond is
probably Lovejoy's prize student.

A ROBE BY ANY OTHER NAME
As Commencement Day draws near, the question on everyone's
lips is:"How did the different disciplines come to be marked by
academic robes with hoods of different colors?" Everybody—
but everybody—is asking it. I mean I haven't been able to walk
ten feet on any campus in America without somebody grabs my
elbow and says, "How did the different disciplines come to be
marked by academic robes with hoods of different colors, hey?"
This, I must say, is not the usual question asked by collegians
who grab my elbow. Usually they say, "Hey, Shorty, got a
Marlboro?" And this is right and proper. After all, are they not
collegians, and, therefore, the nation's leaders in intelligence
and discernment? And do not intelligence and discernment de!nand the tastiest in tobacco flavor and smoking pleasure? And
does not Marlboro deliver a flavor that is uniquely mellow, a
selectrate filter that is easy drawing, a pack that is soft, a box
that is hard? You know it!

But I digress. Back to the colored hoods of academic robes.
A doctor of philosophy wears blue, a doctor of medicine wears
green, a master of arts wears white,a doctor of humanities wears
crimson, a master of library science wears lemon yellow. Why?
Why,for example,should a master of library science wear lemon
yellow?
Well sir, to answer this vexing question, we must go back to
March 29, 1844. On that date the first public library in the
United States was established by Ulric Sigafoos. All of Mr.
Sigafoos's neighbors were of course wildly grateful-=all, that
is, except Wrex Todhunter.
Mr. Todhunter had hated Mr. Sigafoos since.1822 when both
men had wooed the beauteous Melanie Zitt and Melanie had
chosen Mr. Sigafoos because she was mad for dancing and Mr.
Sigafoos knew all the latest steps, like the Missouri Compromise
Mambo, the Shay's Rebellion Schottische, and the James K.
Polk Polka, while Mr. Todhunter, alas, could not dance at all
owing to a wound he had received at the Battle of New Orleans.
(He was struck by a falling praline.)
Consumed with jealousy at the success of Mr. Sigafoos's
library, Mr. Todhunter resolved to open a competing library.
This he did, but he lured not a single patron away from Mr.
Sigafoos."What has Mr. Sigafoos got that I haven't got?" Mr.
Todhunter kept asking himself, and finally the answer came to
him: books.
So Mr.Todhunter stocked his library with lots of dandy books
and soon he was doing more business than his hated rival.
But Mr. Sigafoos struck back. To regain his clientele, he began
serving tea free of charge at his library every afternoon. Thereupon, Mr. Todhunter, not to be outdone, began serving tea
with sugar. Thereupon, Mr. Sigafoos began serving tea with
sugar and cream. Thereupon, Mr, Todhunter began serving
tea with sugar and cream and lemon.
This, of course, clinched the victory for Mr. To.dhunter because he had the only lemon tree in town—in fact, in the entire
state of North Dakota—and since that day lemon yellow has of
course been the color on the academic robes of library science.
(Incidentally, the defeated Mr.Sigafoos packed up his library
and moved to California where, alas, he failed once more. There
were, to be sure, plenty of lemons to serve with his tea, but,
alas, there was no cream because the cow was not introduced
01961 Max Shulman

(Continued from Page 2)
the greatest developments of the
past ten years in biology and
medicine has occurred — the
discovery of the structure of
DNA (deoxyribose nucleic acid)
and of certain proteins by the
application of the methods of
chemistry and physics. These
discovereies have had a tremendous impact on the course of
thought and research in genetics,
biochemistry and microbiology,
as well as very immediate practical applications to the theory
and practice of medicine.
Although there had been important findings concerning the
chemical nature of the nucleic
acids and proteins, it was not
until physical methods — such
as x-ray diffraction analysis of
the crystal structure of these
substances — were applied that
deductions could be made about
the three-dimensional arrangement of the individual atoms
making up these complex molecules. Implicit in these structures are some of the fundamental and central secrets of genetics.
DNA Solved By X-Ray
It had been known that DNA

is the carrier of hereditary information in the cell nucleus,
but the chemical and structural
basis for information coding was
not available until the threedimensional structure of the
DNA molecule was arrived at by
x-ray diffrction and chemical

analysis. These findings led to
the enunciation of the WatsonCrick hypothesis of nucleic acid
structure and DNA replication in
the cell, one of the most influen-tial and significant principles of
biology to be proposed in the
past 25 years.

A multitude of babbling females and an equally vocierous though numerically smaller batch of boys adorned
he steps of the Jesse Doremas Memorial Gymnasium at
iexington, Virginia, where a scholastic press meeting was
session. Hopkins also played lacrosse there that day.
Journalists are natually curious people, and a few of
he guests at Washington and Lee College wandered over
0 the football field to see what all those weirdly-attired
41s with funny-looking sticks i their hands were going
0 do. Maybe a rumble?
When and if those adventurous souls got across the
ongest foot bridge in the world, they did see a gridiron
its goal posts still up. Directly in front of the goals
tere two nests held up by some rusted iron. But more
Inpressive than all this was the imposing steel stands
hich could probably accomodate about five thousand
'Pectators. The stands were practically empty.
Two weeks before, one of the best teams in the nation
taveled to Charlottesville, another Virginia burg, to face
of the more respected teams in stiek circles. This
line the Hopkins aggregation drew two hundred semi‘hebriated Cavaliers and a handful of Jay well-wishers
ho saw the Baltimore team suffer the ignominy of play41g in what amounted to a sawdust pile wedged between
railroad and a busy thoroughfare.
All of which goes to prove that lacrosse is not big
ague in the South. Or anywhere else for that matter.
Lacrosse Coach Bob Scott
faces a problem which is the
exact antithesis to that which
hounds football mentor Wilson Fewster. One has a
sport which is miniscule
throughout the land but
which is gigantic at Hopkins. The other heads a
game which is all the rage
in the country but which is
non-existent at Homewood.
No definite solution to this
perplexing problem will be
forthcoming from this typewriter, but it certainly does
seem a shame that a sport
as exciting — to play and
%etc coach faces strange prob- watch — as the ancient
Indian game should remain so
obscure.

e because some locales wouldn't be able to furnish the
4r1stormers with any opposition.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 5, 1961

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

Hopkins Attends Conf.
About Foreign Affairs
George Powell and Niel Newton, two Hopkins undergraduates, returned this week from
an international relations conference at the Naval Academy
in Annapolis.
The April 26-29 foreign affairs
session, sponsored by the Naval
Academy, the Naval Institute,
and the General Foods Corporation, was attended by 150 students from 60 colleges and universities.
On their arrival, the participants reviewed the Midshipman
brigade and, afterwards, heard
G. Mennen Williams speak at
the Conference's first plenary
session.
A Thursday cruise was followed by a panel discussion
among retired Ambassador to

Pakistan Loy Henderson; Mr.
David Shepard, executive Vice
president of Standard Oil of New
Jersey; Senator Frank Church
of Idaho;-Mr. Edwin Kenworthy,
former head of the New York
Times Washington Bureau; and
Rear Admiral John M. Lee,
chief of the military branch of
the Department of Defense.
The gathering closed with the
drafting of foreign policy resolutions slated to be presented to
the State Department. Among
them were two suggestions advocating a more aggressive policy
in Africa and the Middle East
and a extension of military and
economic aid within the framework of a coordinated long term
—short term policy.

Phi Sigma Delta last week
ended the 115 game winning
streak of Phi Gamma Delta lacrosse team with a convincing
8-7 victory in double overtime.
The loss dropped the Gams into
a three way tie for first place
with ATO and Beta.
In an exclusive interview after
the game, coach Frank Ginsburg
of Phi Sig was quoted as saying, "Although the team did an
excellent job, I think most of
the credit for our great upset
must go to the coach who did a
tremendous job with the terrible
material he had."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 5, 1961

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Dr. Dintzis To Head Medical Grad Students To Visit
And Hygiene Biophysics Dept. Williamsburg Meeting
The appointment of Dr. Howard M. Dintzis as professor of
biophysics and chairman of the
joint department of biophysics
of the Johns Hopkins University
School of Medicine and the
School of Hygiene and Public
Health was announced today by
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, President of the University.
Dr. Dintzis, who received his
bachelor's degree from the University of California and his
doctorate in biophysical chemistry from the Harvard Medical
School, is now a senior research
associate in the department of
biology of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Eisenhower's Statement
In announcing the appointment, Dr. Eisenhower declared:
"The Johns Hopkins University has been fortunate to obtain, in Dr. Dintzis, a brilliant
investigator and teacher in the
field of biophysics, one of the
newest and most significant of
the life sciences.
"Because of the important deexperimental
velopments in
biology ... the faculty has felt
that the training of medical
students in this modern age
would be incomplete without
some appreciation and knowledge of the field of biophysics.
Need Academic Department
"For this reason, the Johns
Hopkins University has decided
to develop a large and significant academic department in
biophysics at its School of Medi-

cine and School of Hygiene and
Public Health and to provide
instruction in biophysics to students at both the elementary and
advanced levels.
"Only a very few medical
schools in the country have such
programs and we hope that this
development, planned on a large
scale, will provide the spearhead
for the foundation of medical
theory and practice on the
fundamental biological, chemical and physical principles that
govern the behavior of molecules
within cells"
To Occupy New Building
Dr. Dintzis, whose appointment becomes effective July 1,
and his department, will occupy
the $1,000,000, four-story Biophysics Building, just completed
at the School of Medicine.

Dr. Dintzis received his bachelor's degree in 1948 and his
Ph.D. in 1953. He then spent two
years as a research fellow in
the molecular biology unit of
the Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, England.
From Cal. Tech.
In 1956, he became assistant
professor of chemistry in the
California Institute of Technology. He was appointed to his
present position at M.I.T. in
1953.
Dr. Dintzis is regarded as an
authority in the structure and
biosynthesis of large molecules
and has made important scientific contributions to the x-ray
analysis of protein structure.

Student Council Plans
Next Year's Activities
The details of getting off the
ground and the sketching in of
tentative plans for some of next
year's activities occupied the
second meeting of the newly
elected Student Council last
Wednesday.
Council President Bob Abernethy announced that- a new
S.C. constitution is in the works
and will probably be presented

to the student body for approval
some time early next year.
It was also announced that
President Milton Eisenhower will
establish a series of informal gettogethers with the Council at his
home next year. These are to be
strictly social events which; it is
hoped, will bring about a greater
mutual understanding between
faculty and students.

Two Johns Hokins University
graduate students have been selected to attend the fifth annual
Williamsburg International Assembly to be held at Williamsburg, Virginia June 11-14.
Guillermo Alarcon of the Department of Sanitary_ Engineering and Luther A. Bourne, a student at the School of Advanced
International Studies, are among
the fifty-two delegates who will
attend.
To be eligible for attendance
a student must be a citizen of a
country other than the United
States who plans to return home
before the start of the next
academic year. He must also
have completed at least one year
of graduate-level study by the
end of the present academic
year.
A native of Bolivia, Mr. Alarcon is being sponsored in the
Department of Engineering by
the Organization of American
States.
Mr. Bourne, whose home is in
the West Indies, is an officer in
the Federal Public Service of the
Federation of the West Indies.
He was sent to SIAS for specialized training by the Prime Minister's Department of the West
Indies.
The topic of the conference will
be "The American Cultural
Scene: Roots and Realities." Informal presentations, question
and answer sessions and general

Hopkins Apathy: What Me Worr And Folk Concert
By MIKE MAKOyER
One of the average Hopkins
student's most serious deficiencies is a lack of any detailed
knowledge about what goes on
in the world. In a recent NewsLetter current events poll the
average score was only 40%.
Twenty questions on current
events were asked of dormitory
students of all classes and
majors. The questions were designed to test a fairly detailed
knowledge of world affairs and
to eliminate blind guessing.
Social science majors made top
scores, followed by students in
the humanities, biological sciences, sciences, and engineering—in descending order. By
class, seniors led, trailed by

juniors, sophomores, and freshmen.
Results on individual questions raised some interesting
points. For example, though
peace organizations and UnAmerican Activities Committee
groups are active at Hopkins,
only 30% of the students knew
that the House had overwhelmingly approved and voted funds
for the Committee.
Again, only 30% could answer
questions on Lao-s, the Congo,
and the U.N., all of which have
been very much in the news. A
surprising 70% did not know that
Lord Home is Foreign Minister
of Great Britain. Less surprising
was the fact that 70% did not
know that Conakry is the capi-

tal of Guinea, or that John Connally is Secretary of the Navy.
The only excuse offered for
low scores was lack of time to
read newspapers. A few students
thought that the questions were
ambiguous, but even if the average score is pro-rated for ambiguity and testing error, its
highest level is 50%, which is not
significantly better.
A minor question asked for
the name of the President of
Russia. The 70% who did not
know the answer (Brezhnev)
guessed Vorlinskya completely
fictitious name.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter this week passes
into the hands of a new editorship. As the newly selected
continuous
staff prepares itself to enter our 65th year of
publication, a restatement of policy and aims is in order.
First, the News-Letter fully recognizes\ its responsibility to provide full carerage for the manifold functions

The News-Letter shall maintain tradition by taking
firm stands on campus issues when the situations warrant
such editorial action. We shall break with tradition by
supporting one candidate or the other in major campus
elections should a case arise in which the issues or personalities involved are clear cut enough.
In a concerted attempt to improve the journalistic
quality of the paper, we shall expand our campus coverage
to encompass hitherto neglected areas such as cultural
affairs, meetings and lectures. In addition our news and
feature columns will include items concerning off-campus
activities of interest to Hopkins men, both in the City of
Baltimore and on other neighboring campuses.
The manifold issues of civil liberties and racial
equality have attracted much interest on the Hopkins
campus this year as in past years. The News-Letter shall
try to elucidate and comment on these issues and the
actions taken thereupon in order to help bring about a
greater degree of equality, both on and off the campus.
This is in accordance with long' established News-Letter
policy.
As a final break with tradition, the News-Letter will
no longer refrain from commenting upon and taking firm
stands on major national and international issues. While
our principal function is as a campus organ, there are
,often timely issues in the daily newspapers which warrant
student opinion and reaction in the nature of editorials
and news analyses. This shall be a fairly regular feature
of a News-Letter truly representative of student activities,
opinion and attitudes.

By MATT iCRENSON

Dr. Albert Hammond, after half a century
spent with the queen of Arts and the sport of
kings, has announced that he will retire from
daytime teaching at Hopkins this June.
Dr. Hammond, Associate Professor of Philosophy, began his association with the University
in 1910 when he arrived at the old Howard
Street campus as a freshman. Today he recalls
that the location at Howard and Ross Streets
was somewhat superior to the present Homewood site in that the width of Ross Street was
ideal for pitching nickels.
As an undergraduate, Dr. Hamomnd was a
member of the "historical-political group"
(there were no department majors), and he
took the required courses—English composition,
literature, physics and philosophy, which in
those days covered ethics, psychology, and logic
in one year.
In 1914, he turned to teaching—at first in
public speaking and later, in philosophy.

A ROBE BY ANY OTHER NAME
As Commencement Day draws near, the question on everyone's
lips is:"How did the different disciplines come to be marked by
academic robes with hoods of different colors?" Everybody—
but everybody—is asking it. I mean I haven't been able to walk
ten feet on any campus in America without somebody grabs my
elbow and says, "How did the different disciplines come to be
marked by academic robes with hoods of different colors, hey?"
This, I must say, is not the usual question asked by collegians
who grab my elbow. Usually they say, "Hey, Shorty, got a
Marlboro?" And this is right and proper. After all, are they not
collegians, and, therefore, the nation's leaders in intelligence
and discernment? And do not intelligence and discernment de!nand the tastiest in tobacco flavor and smoking pleasure? And
does not Marlboro deliver a flavor that is uniquely mellow, a
selectrate filter that is easy drawing, a pack that is soft, a box
that is hard? You know it!

under his not so very large belt.

But I digress. Back to the colored hoods of academic robes.
A doctor of philosophy wears blue, a doctor of medicine wears
green, a master of arts wears white,a doctor of humanities wears
crimson, a master of library science wears lemon yellow. Why?
Why,for example,should a master of library science wear lemon
yellow?
Well sir, to answer this vexing question, we must go back to
March 29, 1844. On that date the first public library in the
United States was established by Ulric Sigafoos. All of Mr.
Sigafoos's neighbors were of course wildly grateful-=all, that
is, except Wrex Todhunter.
Mr. Todhunter had hated Mr. Sigafoos since.1822 when both
men had wooed the beauteous Melanie Zitt and Melanie had
chosen Mr. Sigafoos because she was mad for dancing and Mr.
Sigafoos knew all the latest steps, like the Missouri Compromise
Mambo, the Shay's Rebellion Schottische, and the James K.
Polk Polka, while Mr. Todhunter, alas, could not dance at all
owing to a wound he had received at the Battle of New Orleans.
(He was struck by a falling praline.)
Consumed with jealousy at the success of Mr. Sigafoos's
library, Mr. Todhunter resolved to open a competing library.
This he did, but he lured not a single patron away from Mr.
Sigafoos."What has Mr. Sigafoos got that I haven't got?" Mr.
Todhunter kept asking himself, and finally the answer came to
him: books.
So Mr.Todhunter stocked his library with lots of dandy books
and soon he was doing more business than his hated rival.
But Mr. Sigafoos struck back. To regain his clientele, he began
serving tea free of charge at his library every afternoon. Thereupon, Mr. Todhunter, not to be outdone, began serving tea
with sugar. Thereupon, Mr. Sigafoos began serving tea with
sugar and cream. Thereupon, Mr, Todhunter began serving
tea with sugar and cream and lemon.
This, of course, clinched the victory for Mr. To.dhunter because he had the only lemon tree in town—in fact, in the entire
state of North Dakota—and since that day lemon yellow has of
course been the color on the academic robes of library science.
(Incidentally, the defeated Mr.Sigafoos packed up his library
and moved to California where, alas, he failed once more. There
were, to be sure, plenty of lemons to serve with his tea, but,
alas, there was no cream because the cow was not introduced

Phi Gamma Delta, as a part
Of their year long charity work,

program collect over $200 during
this Spring's drive.
The Hopkins fraternity distributed over 200 Easter Seal
Campaign cans to merchants
covering a territory between
North Avenue and Baltimore
Street which was eight blocks
wide.
This Easter Seal campaign
was part of a year long program
conducted by Phi Gam which
has included an Orphan's party
at Christmas, a Cancer fund
dr1've, a Muscular Dystrophy
drive, and a help day during
which the Phi Gam pledges each
spent eight hours at an orphanage. This last function was in
place of the usual fraternity Hell
Night.
According to Dick Ryan, past
president of Phi Gam, the fraternity tries to schedule at least
one charity project each month.
Ryan went on to add that "We
feel our charity work is as important part of our fraternity as
anything else."

the greatest developments of the
past ten years in biology and
medicine has occurred — the
discovery of the structure of
DNA (deoxyribose nucleic acid)
and of certain proteins by the
application of the methods of
chemistry and physics. These
discovereies have had a tremendous impact on the course of
thought and research in genetics,
biochemistry and microbiology,
as well as very immediate practical applications to the theory
and practice of medicine.
Although there had been important findings concerning the
chemical nature of the nucleic
acids and proteins, it was not
until physical methods — such
as x-ray diffraction analysis of
the crystal structure of these
substances — were applied that
deductions could be made about
the three-dimensional arrangement of the individual atoms
making up these complex molecules. Implicit in these structures are some of the fundamental and central secrets of genetics.
DNA Solved By X-Ray
It had been known that DNA

is the carrier of hereditary information in the cell nucleus,
but the chemical and structural
basis for information coding was
not available until the threedimensional structure of the
DNA molecule was arrived at by
x-ray diffrction and chemical

analysis. These findings led to
the enunciation of the WatsonCrick hypothesis of nucleic acid
structure and DNA replication in
the cell, one of the most influen-tial and significant principles of
biology to be proposed in the
past 25 years.

yet I stay awake nights worrying about my ability to teach today's bright young college students. They ask questions I can't answer. They

How can I possibly hope to win the respect of
students who are more learned than I an?

Professor
DEAR PROFESSOR: I always maintain that nothing impresses a troublesome student like the
sharp slap of a ruler across his outstretched
palm.

A multitude of babbling females and an equally vocierous though numerically smaller batch of boys adorned
he steps of the Jesse Doremas Memorial Gymnasium at
iexington, Virginia, where a scholastic press meeting was
session. Hopkins also played lacrosse there that day.
Journalists are natually curious people, and a few of
he guests at Washington and Lee College wandered over
0 the football field to see what all those weirdly-attired
41s with funny-looking sticks i their hands were going
0 do. Maybe a rumble?
When and if those adventurous souls got across the
ongest foot bridge in the world, they did see a gridiron
its goal posts still up. Directly in front of the goals
tere two nests held up by some rusted iron. But more
Inpressive than all this was the imposing steel stands
hich could probably accomodate about five thousand
'Pectators. The stands were practically empty.
Two weeks before, one of the best teams in the nation
taveled to Charlottesville, another Virginia burg, to face
of the more respected teams in stiek circles. This
line the Hopkins aggregation drew two hundred semi‘hebriated Cavaliers and a handful of Jay well-wishers
ho saw the Baltimore team suffer the ignominy of play41g in what amounted to a sawdust pile wedged between
railroad and a busy thoroughfare.
All of which goes to prove that lacrosse is not big
ague in the South. Or anywhere else for that matter.
Lacrosse Coach Bob Scott
faces a problem which is the
exact antithesis to that which
hounds football mentor Wilson Fewster. One has a
sport which is miniscule
throughout the land but
which is gigantic at Hopkins. The other heads a
game which is all the rage
in the country but which is
non-existent at Homewood.
No definite solution to this
perplexing problem will be
forthcoming from this typewriter, but it certainly does
seem a shame that a sport
as exciting — to play and
%etc coach faces strange prob- watch — as the ancient
Indian game should remain so
obscure.
One half-way measure which might create some intert would be a barnstorming tour over the summer. In'ILead of sending envoys abroad, it might be more prudent
Sponsor a trip to the Mid-West in an attempt to genate interest. Two teams might be more efficacious than
e because some locales wouldn't be able to furnish the
4r1stormers with any opposition.

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

Hopkins Attends Conf.
About Foreign Affairs
George Powell and Niel Newton, two Hopkins undergraduates, returned this week from
an international relations conference at the Naval Academy
in Annapolis.
The April 26-29 foreign affairs
session, sponsored by the Naval
Academy, the Naval Institute,
and the General Foods Corporation, was attended by 150 students from 60 colleges and universities.
On their arrival, the participants reviewed the Midshipman
brigade and, afterwards, heard
G. Mennen Williams speak at
the Conference's first plenary
session.
A Thursday cruise was followed by a panel discussion
among retired Ambassador to

Pakistan Loy Henderson; Mr.
David Shepard, executive Vice
president of Standard Oil of New
Jersey; Senator Frank Church
of Idaho;-Mr. Edwin Kenworthy,
former head of the New York
Times Washington Bureau; and
Rear Admiral John M. Lee,
chief of the military branch of
the Department of Defense.
The gathering closed with the
drafting of foreign policy resolutions slated to be presented to
the State Department. Among
them were two suggestions advocating a more aggressive policy
in Africa and the Middle East
and a extension of military and
economic aid within the framework of a coordinated long term
—short term policy.

BIA's
Phi Sigma Delta last week
ended the 115 game winning
streak of Phi Gamma Delta lacrosse team with a convincing
8-7 victory in double overtime.
The loss dropped the Gams into
a three way tie for first place
with ATO and Beta.
In an exclusive interview after
the game, coach Frank Ginsburg
of Phi Sig was quoted as saying, "Although the team did an
excellent job, I think most of
the credit for our great upset
must go to the coach who did a
tremendous job with the terrible
material he had."
